title: I am 38 and in debt so can I access my pension early?
text:
I've around £150,000 in my SIPP (Self-Invested Personal Pension) but have fallen on hard times and run up a lot of personal debt.

Is there any way I can pay a penalty and access these funds? I'm 38 so I've plenty of time to replace them.

SCROLL DOWN TO FIND OUT HOW TO ASK YOUR PENSION QUESTION

Pension savings: Retirement pots are intended to stay locked up until you are 55 - you can tap them early, but there is a heavy tax penalty

Steve Webb replies: As you know, when you put money into a pension you are making a long-term commitment.

You benefit from the advantage of tax relief on your pension contributions and in return for this your money is locked up until you are older, normally at least 55 years old.

Whilst it is not illegal to access the money in your pension before this date, it is very unlikely to be the best course of action, for a number of reasons.

First of all, there are many scammers who try to encourage people to access their pension pot before the age of 55.

There are dozens of examples online of companies who will tell you that they have found a special way round the rules or that they can get you a great return on your money and so on.

But in the vast majority of cases you are at real risk of losing some or all of your money.

As well as the tax penalties you face (of which more below), these companies often deduct huge fees and then frequently want to invest your money in somewhere high risk and often outside the UK.

These sorts of schemes raise so many 'red flags' from a point of view of the risk of being scammed, they should simply be ignored.

Second, as you know, there is a significant tax charge associated with taking money out of a pension before the permitted age.

Money that comes out of a pension is subject to income tax in any case (apart from any tax free lump sum), but when you make what is called an 'unauthorised' withdrawal, you face an extra tax hit.

As the Government's website confirms such withdrawals can be taxed at up to 55 per cent, depending on what proportion of the pot is withdrawn.

The main exception to this would be someone who is seriously ill, to whom different rules can apply.

I do however appreciate that you have debts and an urgent need for money, so it is understandable that you are considering all options.

In your situation, probably the first thing to do would be to speak to experts in managing debts.

There are a number of organisations that offer free or low cost help and advice. Larger ones include specialist charities such as StepChange or Christians Against Poverty.

In some cases they can help to get debts written off completely or they can help to negotiate with creditors to allow things like repayment holidays or reduced repayments.

The right strategy will depend on the level and nature of your debts, but it is well worth talking to a debt counsellor who might be able to come up with ideas that you had not thought of.

One final point is that if you are in employment, especially with a large firm, you might find that your employer is far more supportive than you would expect.

Some workplaces have 'employee assistance programmes' where staff can get confidential support on a range of areas.

Other firms are very focused on the 'financial well-being' of their staff because workers with money worries may not be as productive at work.

Although it can be embarrassing talking about your financial problems to your employer, you may find that you get a more positive response than you expected.

All of these avenues are worth pursuing – and exhausting – before contemplating taking 'unauthorised' funds out of your pension.
